titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:30. Bath with George— The Count de Menou called at the Office: just returned from New-York, hither he accompanied the Baron de Neuville, to his embarkation. He told me he had seen my wife’sbrother last week at Philadelphia; and thought him rather improving in his health— I attended the Theatre this Evening, and saw Richard the Third, with the Rendez-vous, or Hide and Seek; the second time, this Season— The part of Richard was performed by Booth, who belonged to the strolling company of English Players whom I saw at Ghent; and who afterwards just before I left England, broke out, as a first rate actor and rival of Kean— He was then a mere copy of Kean, but is not so now— His performance of Richard was tame and flat. Seemingly with little effort to please, and little regard for the Audience. The house was well-filled. The most interesting Scenes of the Play; the murder of king Henry—The courtship of Lady Anne, and the tent Scene, were all balked, dismally. The Play itself is very absurd, and interesting principally by the character of Richard— There are few English actors capable of understanding Shakespeare, and Booth is not one of them. Warren’s king Henry was well performed, but he is too fat for the part— The farce was hardly worth seeing a second time.

2. V:30. Bath with George. Lieutenant Sherburne called this morning at my house to tell me that he was not unmindful of the kindness of my interposition in his favour; by which he had obtained the promotion that he claimed, and also a suspension of the order to go upon the Coast of Florida to survey during the sickly Season. He said he would call again to shew me some of his Charts— At the Office there was a Mr Chalmers, and Edward Wyer— There was this Evening an Eclipse of the Moon, at which we looked with Dr Thornton through a small and indifferent Telescope, in the Street; opposite to my house. There were nine or ten digits eclipsed, and it continued between three and four hours. This Eclipse presented the unusual phenomenon, of a lunar eclipse commenced, before the apparent setting of the Sun. But the haziness of the atmosphere at the horizon prevented the observation of it. I wrote to my wife.

3. V:30. Bath with George. Passed the Office hours without interruption. There is in the Argus of Western America, a Newspaper published at Frankfort Kentucky, under date of the 18th. of July, an Article, apparently Editorial, headed The Ghent Mission, which both from its Style and Contents I take to have been written by Mr Clay: but if not, certainly from him indirectly— It is bitter upon
“the Secretary,” and apologizes for Clay’s having agreed to the Mississippi proposition, upon the plea of the new Instructions— It abandons all Russell’s pretences, and says that Clay thought the Government ought not to have given the Instructions— Clay’s conduct throughout this affair towards me, has been that of an envious rival—a fellow-servant whispering tales into the ear of the common master. He has been seven years circulating this poison against me, in the West, and I have now no doubt that Russell’s Letter was brought forth upon suggestions originating with him— Russell has all along performed for him the part of a Jackall— Clay seems to have fancied that I should have no means of self-vindication if Russell’s Letter should be brought before Congress, and this Article in the Argus evidently betrays his vexation and disappointment at the result— Evening at the Play— Colman’s Iron Chest; and The Spoil’d child— Booth as Sir Edward Mortimer, and Johnston as Wilford. I had never before seen the Iron Chest which is a Tragi-comedy, from Godwin’s Caleb Williams. I was much better pleased with Booth this Evening than in Richard— The Characters of Shakespear, are like the bow of Ulysses—Actors very good in all others parts sink in the attempt at representing them— Mrs Burke is good in the character of Little Pickle, and seems fond of playing it.

4. V:30. Bath with George, and a Spring tide— Heard Mr Little; from 1. Timothy 4.7. [“]But refuse profane and old wives’ fables, and exercise thyself rather unto godliness.” This was a moral essay against petty superstitions, or old wives fables— After the service, I had a visit from Mr John Law. The latter part of the day was Showery, and the attendance at Meeting for the Evening so thin, that Mr Little dismissed the congregation, with a short prayer; omitting the Sermon, and the other parts of the Service— There is in the Richmond Enquirer of the 2. instt. which came this day, a jesuitical and most insidious Article upon the Diplomatic controversy. It begins by copying from the Charleston S.C. Courier an Article upon it very severe upon Russell, with which it expresses concurrence in part, but cavils at some comment in it upon Floyd, and instigates Floyd to come out against it— Then it pronounces Russell decidedly in fault in the “quarrel about the duplicate”—and with the same dogmatism pronounces that the proposition made to the British at Ghent seems to defy all justification— Extracts all the part of the sham Editorial Article in the Frankfort Argus, which charges “the Secretary” and calls upon me to answer it—but omits all that part of the same Article which contains Clay’s admissions of his having assented and subscribed to the proposition— The main object of the Richmond Enquirers instigators in this affair is to blow the Coals— They want to bring in Floyd and Clay, to fall upon me; and help out Russell; for considering him as already disgraced before the Nation they wish to uphold him just enough to assist him in his notable attempt to disgrace me— At the first explosion of this affair, they could not suppress their exultation at the prospect of two distinguished Massachusetts Men afoul of each other, and sure, both to lose character by the result. But the burst of public Sentiment, was so quick and so strong against Russell, on the publication of his Duplicate Letters and my Remarks, that in a few days the Richmond Enquirer gave out that I had seized with great ability, upon this occasion to make myself a Party for the next Presidential Election, for which it declared I was before, quite out of the question. The Richmond Enquirer is the organ of a great and predominating political party in Virginia. It is the Main Spring for Mr Crawford’s Election, in that State, and indeed throughout the Union— It is the very Mrs. Candour of Newspapers, and under an affectation of impartiality and liberality has been and
will be managed with the most inveterate hostility to me. I have concluded to publish the papers of this controversy in a pamphlet, and have prepared a paper to be published in the National Intelligencer, announcing this Intention.

5. V:30. Bath with George— The last time of the Morning tides at present— Morning Call from T. Cook, just returned from Philadelphia— Lieutenant Sherburne called at my house again with his Charts, and a French Louisianian wrote me a Letter, and sent me two small parcels of dried herbs which he says grew in Nova-Scotia, and are much superior for tea, to that of China— That he was first treated with this Tea by the Duke of Richmond, who told him that it grew very abundantly in Nova-Scotia; but that it would be dangerous that their neighbours should discover the existence there of this inestimable treasure, and still more dangerous for England that the use of this tea should become general— Whether Mr Leduc is of the Class of Lunatics, or that of Imposters, is the alternative. Captain O’Brien and E. Wyer were at the Office— In the Evening I walked to Mr Frye’s. A northwest wind has brought cool weather.

6. V:30. I sent this morning to Mr Force, requesting him to call at the Office of the Department of State which he did. I told him I proposed to publish a pamphlet containing the Message of the President to the House of Representatives, with the residuary Ghent Treaty Documents— The Message, with the Duplicate Letters and my Remarks; Mr Russell’s subsequent publications in the newspapers relating to this subject and mine; with additional papers, amounting perhaps to 100 pages more— I asked him, if he would undertake the publication at his own expense, and risk. He said he would, and I gave him a printed copy of the Ghent Document Message to begin with. He said he would commence the publication in a few days, and I engaged to furnish him from time to time, with copy, as it should be wanted— Mr Seaton of the National Intelligencer likewise called, and I gave him the paper which I had prepared, announcing my purpose of withdrawing the subject from the Newspapers, and of publishing all the Documents in a pamphlet— Mr Marrast an applicant for Office, and Mr W. G. D. Worthington, late Secretary for East Florida, were at the Office. Worthington under the new organization of the Government was appointed Marshal for East-Florida, but says he thinks he shall decline the appointment. He has lately returned from St. Augustine to Baltimore. Worthington is a shallow, inflated coxcomb, meaning to be honest, fancying himself profound and eloquent, and making himself every where ridiculous in the superlative degree— He has powerful friends who are in permanent session of importunity to the President to attain places for him— And when he gets them, he soon contrives to work himself out of them— Evening at the Play— Lear (Booth) and The Devil to pay— Booth’s Lear, was worse than his Richard— The Play itself, full of beauties and sublimities, is also full of absurdity— Lear begins with too much folly as well as injustice to be an interesting character— The changes from the original Play, destroys its effect as a moral lesson. The great interest of the tragedy consists in the contrast of filial duty and affection, with filial ingratitude— The lovely character is Cordelia; and its loveliness consists in her filial piety— But her amour with Edgar is a great debasement of her and the restoration of Lear to the crown, is a childish perversion of Shakespear. Booth could not speak any of the fine passages of this play, better than he did those of Richard, and I who after a lapse of six and twenty years seem as if I were yet hearing John Kemble pronounce
“That she may feel
How sharper than a Serpent’s tooth it is
To have a thankless child.” 20. Novr 1795.
can even now hardly remember how they were spoken by Booth— In the farce Jefferson performed the part of Jobson as well as I had ever seen it performed, but Mrs Burke could not stand the comparison either with Mrs Jordan, or with the admirable actress and singer, in the Italian Opera Buffa at Dresden.

7. VI:30. My paper was published this Morning in the National Intelligencer. Mr George Hay called upon me at my house, and expressed his approbation of it, but said there was one passage in it which upon a first, second, and third reading he had not been able to understand— It presented at the first reading a sense which it was impossible should be intended— He had finally discerned its meaning, and then had wondered how he could have had any hesitation about it— The passage speaks of Russell’s Letter as having been “trumpeted beforehand throughout the Union, as fraught with disclosures, which were to blast a reputation, worthless in the estimation of its possessor if not unsullied.” I saw upon examining this sentence that there was something in it not perfectly clear; and that it would have been better to transpose the word worthless and say “a reputation, in the estimation of its possessor, worthless if not unsullied.” I told Mr Hay that I had been obliged to publish this paper, without having the benefit of previous revisal by a friend—and asked him if he would do me that favour for the next paper of the collection—for the accuracy of which I should feel more solicitude. He said he would. I mentioned to Mr Hay the disingenuous manner in which the Richmond Enquirer, had republished a part, and suppressed a part of the Article in the Frankfort Argus of 18 July. He said I should never experience fairness or candour from the Richmond Enquirer— That paper would not resort to positive falsehood; but they would not give the whole truth— I was without interruption this day at the Office, and spent the Evening at Dr Thornton’s.

8. V:30. I received this Morning from England, the copies of the yard and Ell Measures from the English Exchequer which I had ordered. A fac simile of each of the Bars called the Standard Yard and Ell of Elizabeth, or of 1601. of Brass— And with them there is another Brass Bar four feet long, upon which are marked by lines traced upon inlaid silver, the exact length of the same yard and Ell. They are all fitted into beds, in a Mahogany Case, under Lock and Key— We have now Copies of the Standard Weights and Measures both of France and Great Britain, as exact as could possibly be obtained— I received from MrC. A. Rodney, the Senator from the State of Delaware, the second Volume of Chalmers’s Collection of Opinions of eminent Lawyers, containing the opinions of the Attornies and Solicitors General, at three several periods, after intervening Wars, that the Treaty of Neutrality of 1686 was yet in force, though not renewed, nor specifically mentioned in any of the Treaties of Peace— Also the Advocate General Sir James Marryat’s Opinion and argument upon it in 1765— Rodney has taken interest in this Controversy, as he told me, from his regard for the memory of Mr Bayard, who was his fellow-Citizen of Delaware, brother at the Bar, rival Statesman, and personal friend— He first mentioned to me the debates in Parliament on the Peace of Amiens; and a few days since, I received a Letter from him, speaking of these authorities in Chalmers’s Book: and also of a reference to and inference from them in a volume upon Commercial Law, recently published by Chitty. He offered me the loan of the Books, which I accepted. Evening at the Play. Town and Country—a Modern sermonizing Comedy, I believe, by Morton— The part of Reuben Glenroy by Booth— A gloomy, sentimental, Country hero. The Town hero is Cosey, a Banker; cheerful, witty, something ridiculous, but rich as the purse of Fortunatus, and generous in proposition. Very pleasant,
however, and performed as well as possible by Jefferson— The farce was the Weathercock, or Love alone can fix him, in which Jefferson again exercised us with laughter in Tristram Fickle.

9. VI.Mr Force the Printer came this morning to my house, and I gave him papers for printing in the proposed pamphlet, sufficient to occupy his Press and Compositors for a fortnight. He is to send me the proof Sheets for revisal, and to leave the first sheet and a half or 12 pages for the title page and Introduction— The President returned from his short visit to his Country Seat at Loudoun, and I called at his house, with papers received during his absence— Captain O’Brien came and took leave having attained the settlement of his accounts, as far as the Acts of Congress in his favour would admit. But he has yet large claims in reserve, and he has been indefatigable in his exertions to induce me to strain the Construction of the Acts, to the admission of claims expressly excluded by them— I have found it difficult to resist his importunities, his playful humours, his claims from real services and sufferings, his coarse but original eloquence, and his artful, and disguised flatteries learnt in a ten years apprenticeship in servitude to a Dey of Algiers. There can be no more instructive School for learning some of the operations of the human heart, and the arts of dissimulation. O’Brien’s character is a compound of the roughness of a Jack tar, with the oily suppleness of a Courtier. The ingredients are so incongruous that the mixture forms one of the greatest oddities I have ever met with— Mr George Hay called likewise at the Office; and I gave him the first paper of my further Strictures upon Russell, asking him to look over it and give me his opinion concerning it which he promised he would— Johnson Hellen came down from Rockville to pay us a visit. Baron Stackelberg the Chargé d’Affaires from Sweden called this Evening at my house; and spoke of his own situation as being very unpleasant. He said his Government allowed him only 3000 dollars a year, which he had repeatedly written to them was insufficient to support him— That upon his first representations a further allowance of 500 dollars was made him for that year, and hopes and promises were held out to him of something further. But nothing was done. Last year he had renewed his solicitations and requested if he could not be otherwise indulged, leave of absence for a year. Count Engeström had answered him, not refusing the leave of absence; but advising him to postpone availing himself of it, and giving him hopes, that the character and emoluments of Consul General would be given him in addition to those of Chargé d’Affaires. But now, Mr Severin Lorich had been to Sweden, and just returned with a Commission of Consul General as he should officially announce to me tomorrow, and he himself had not a single line from Count d’Engeström, and knew not what was to become of himself. He had been under the necessity of contracting debts, and had borrowed money of Mr Poletica, the late Russian Minister, to whom he had been obliged to disclose his embarrassments. He said he came to tell me this and wished me to make it known to the President, that if any thing should occur which might give notoriety to his situation, this Government might attribute it to its proper cause. The Salary of Mr Lorich, as Consul General, he said was 2500 dollars— He did not more explicitly unfold his motive for this communication and I did not ask him for further explanation.

10. V:30.Mr Richard Bland Lee called this morning at my house with a Mr Dennyman, from Virginia, who is a solicitor for employment— A woman by the name of Bridget Smith came to apply for a pardon for her brother, the man who is in prison at Boston for Slave-trading— Miss Smith operated with the usual female weapon, a shower of tears. It seldom fails to disconcert my philosophy, especially when I see the Spring is from the social affections— Here it was a brother—necessary for the comfort and subsistence of a mother— I promised to do my best to obtain his release
though in his own person he has very little claim to mercy, or even to compassion. There was a Mr Murry came to the Office, and Baron Stackelberg brought and delivered a Letter from himself, enclosing the Commission of Severin Lorich, as Consul General of Sweden, and requesting for him an exequator— Evening at the Play—The Mountaineers and All The World’s a Stage. Booth in Octavian. It is the Story of Cardenio in Don Quixot— It is an amusing Play, but Octavian is much less interesting than Cardenio— There is a good Irish character; and the Moors themselves are Irish Christians— In the Farce, all the personages are dramatists— Diggory the footman, the most comically so, as well represented by Jefferson. There was between the Plays a Hornpipe by Miss Hathwell.

11: VI. Heard Mr Little, in the Morning from Psalm 100.3.4 “Know ye that the Lord, he is God: it is he that hath made us, and not we ourselves; we are his people, and the sheep of his pasture— Enter into his gates with thanksgiving, and into his Courts with praise; be thankful unto him, and bless his name.”— A sermon on the character, and unity of God—The Evening text was from Titus 2.11 and 12. “For the grace of God that bringeth Salvation hath appeared to all men,—Teaching us, that denying ungodliness, and worldly lusts, we should live soberly, righteously and godly, in this present world:[”] Mr Little gave notice that he was about going a journey, for his health, and should be absent several weeks, during which the services of the Church would be suspended— Judge Cranch and his Son William came to my house between the Services— The judge desired me if I should fall sick during the absence of Mrs Adams, to send immediately for him— He said it was true that the Episcopalians of Virginia declined receiving him as a communicant, after he had given them notice that he was a Unitarian. I now receive Letters from my wife almost every day.

12. V:30. Began again my morning Baths in the Potowmack with George— Dr. Thornton called this morning and invited me with Johnson Hellen and George to dine at his house with Mr David Peter’s family who were to spend the day with them. We accepted; excepting Johnson Hellen who was to dine at Mr Frye’s— We went between four and five O’Clock, and dined, but only with the Doctor’s own family— Mrs Peter while there in the morning had received information of the death of Mrs Rogers, wife of Lloyd N. Rogers, and daughter of Mrs Law, the Sister of Mrs Peter. They had therefore immediately returned home— Mr Frye was at my house this Evening— The weather aggressively warm. I received this day a despatch from R. Rush, with a printed Copy of the Act of Parliament passed the 24th. of June last, opening the Ports of the British Colonies in the West-Indies, North and South-America, and in the Island of Newfoundland to the Vessels of the United States. I took them to the President’s and mentioned to him the necessity of issuing a Proclamation conformably to the Act of Congress of the last Session, which I promised to prepare and bring to him to-morrow.

13. V:30. Bath with George. William Elliot of the Patent Office, and a Mr Peake were at the Office. I made a draught of a Proclamation opening the Ports of the United States to British Vessels from their Colonies; and took it to the President. I found several difficulties in making the draught. The Act of Congress of 6 May last, authorizes the President by Proclamation to open the Ports of the United States, on certain contingencies to British Vessels employed in the trade and intercourse between the United States and the British Colonies or Islands in the West-Indies, under such reciprocal rules and restrictions as he may prescribe, anything in the two Navigation Acts to the contrary notwithstanding— The British Act of Parliament of 24 June, opens certain Ports by name
in the West Indies, in North and South-America, and in Newfoundland; under certain restrictions of duties, and authorizing only the importation directly of articles the growth produce or manufacture of the United States. As the Act of Congress speaks only of the British Islands or Colonies in the West-Indies, the first question was whether the Proclamation can open our Ports to British Vessels from Newfoundland, North and South America, under the general denomination of the West-Indies— If it cannot, it cannot meet the Act of Parliament, and will be of no effect— I therefore made the draught opening our Ports to vessels, from all the Ports opened to our vessels by the Act of Parliament, construing the term West-Indies as used in the Act of Congress in its most extensive and general sense— The next question was as to the reciprocal rules and restrictions; it occurred to me that under that provision the Proclamation might exact countervailing duties; but as that might be thought to encroach upon the revenue-raising power, I thought it would be best to leave it to Congress— To countervail the restriction of direct trade, I limited the importations from each Colony in British Vessels to the productions of that Colony— I left the draught with the President for his Consideration— Evening at the Play. Hamlet; and the Mayor of Garratt, for Booth’s benefit, and the last Night of his performance— He played Hamlet and Jerry Sneak—both indifferently— He is utterly incompetent to the conception of the character of Hamlet, the most exquisitely drawn tragical character in the whole compass of the drama. A mind deeply meditative, with ardent sensibility, and a pure and lofty sense of rectitude, wrought up by the murder of his father by the incest of his Mother, by the Summons of his fathers Spirit from the sufferings of purgatory, by the usurpation of his own rights to the succession and by the pangs of disappointed love, to a partial melancholy alienation of mind; complicated by a purposely simulated madness— This is I think the real character of Hamlet, and explains all its seeming inconsistencies. Booth’s Jerry Sneak, was disgusting by its indecency, and not even comical. He sung a filthy song, poorly. The Play itself is not fit to be seen.

14. V:15. Bath with George. Johnson Hellen left us and returned to Rockville. The Count de Menou came to the Office with some enquiries concerning the suit of Captain Edon of the Apollon, against the Collector of St. Marys, Georgia. The District judge decided against the Collector, pro forma, and persons were appointed to assess damages, who estimated them at 25000 dollars. Menou came to say that he was informed an appeal had been entered to the Circuit Court against this decision by orders from Washington, and he wished to know what was intended to be done with it— I told him that I did not know an appeal had gotten entered. That it might have been done by orders from the Treasury Department, of which it would be well for him to enquire. Mr Ringgold with a Mr M’Pherson were at the Office. The latter soliciting a Consular appointment. He is brother to the officer slain with General Montgomery at Quebec. I called at the President’s, and he returned me the draft of the Proclamation opening our Ports to British Vessels from the Colonial Ports opened to ours by the Act of Parliament of 24 June, with a question whether the restriction of importations in the British vessels be admitted to Articles the produce of only the Colony from which they directly come, would not be objectionable— He desired me to consider this, but said he would sign the Proclamation as I had drawn it, if I should conclude, it would be best. He desired me also to shew it to Mr Calhoun, the only other head of Department now here; and to take his advice— I took the draft accordingly this Evening to Mr Calhoun’s, and read it to him suggesting the questions which had occurred to me in drawing it up— I left it with him, and also a Copy
of the British Act of Parliament of 24 June, he will return them to me with his opinion to-morrow Morning. I asked him to consider how a restriction upon the Articles to be imported in British vessels, not limited to Articles of the particular Colony from which they come, but to Articles the produce of the British West India Colonies, for vessels coming from them, and to North American Articles, for vessels from the North-American Articles, would answer.

15. V:15. Bath with George. Mr Calhoun called after breakfast at my house, and returned the draft of the Proclamation, and the Copy of the British Act of Parliament. He thought the restriction last proposed by me, would be more expedient than that limited to the productions of the particular Colony from which the vessel comes— As to the question about opening our Ports to British Vessels from the North American British Provinces under the Act of Congress, which names only the West-Indies; he advised me to write to Mr R. King the Senator, who as Chairman of the Senatorial Committee of Foreign Relations brought in the Bill, and carried it through that Body; and to consult him as to the propriety of extending to the Act that Latitude of Construction. I wrote accordingly to Mr King, mentioning the questions to him, and enclosing the draft of the Proclamation, and the copy of the British Act of Parliament— The Proclamation must of course be for some days delayed. Lieutenant Gordon was at the Office, and gave some further explanations of his claim for having had Mr Shaler on board of his vessel in the Mediterranean. Mr Jonathan Swift also came with a Note from the President, to whom he had delivered an autograph Letter from the king of the Netherlands— The Note directed that the answer should also be transmitted through the hands of Mr Swift, who is the Consul of the Netherlands at Alexandria— Evening at the Play— The Heart of Mid Lothian, or The Lilly of St. Leonard’s, a Melo-drama, by T. Dibdin from the Tales of my Landlord. The Laird of Dumbedikes by Jefferson gave something like Spirit to the Performance— The rest was dull; and the Farce or Comic opera of “Turn out,” was not much better.

16. V:30. Bath with George. Dr Thornton called at my house this morning. William S. Smith was here; and afterwards at my Office. He and his wife have just returned from Pensacola. He was about fourteen Months since appointed Naval Officer at that place, and went there. After the experience of a year he found that it would not supply him with a subsistence; and concluded to return here— He was a Clerk in the Land-Office, and was promised that the place should be kept open for him for a year, in case he should find it necessary to return; he now comes, and must solicit to be restored— Lieutenant Gordon was at the Office— His claim is to be reduced to about one half, and he is to obtain a declaration from Mr Shaler, that he was on special public service on board the ship— Evening walk to Mr Frye’s— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith were there. I this day received a Letter from C. A. Rodney the Senator from Delaware, with a new English authority against the doctrine that all Treaties are abrogated by War. It is the opinion of Mr Fox expressed in Parliament, in the debate on the definitive Treaty of Peace of 1783. And I this day finished the draught of remarks, which I propose to publish in my collection of documents, upon the Editorial Article in the Argus of Western America, which I suppose to have been written by Mr Clay— Force has begun the printing of the work, and sends me usually one proof sheet of eight pages for revisal each week day. This and the necessary writing, for the publication absorbs all my leisure time and all my faculties.

17. VI: Bath with George. Coll. Bomford and Edward Wyer were this Morning at my house, and Lieutenant Gordon, at the Office, where his claim was finally adjusted. I called this Evening at Mrs Wilson’s, where Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith are lodging. Mrs and Miss Forrest and Mr and Mrs R. Cutts came in while I was there. The day was intensely hot.— I had been several days without receiving a Letter from my wife, until yesterday when the Journal for six days came at once. She has been quite ill as I had apprehended from the interruption of her Letters, but has recovered, and this day I received the usual journalizing Letter. She has also sent me a Letter from my brother Thomas to her, giving an account of my father’s donation to the Town of Quincy— Eighty Acres of Mount Ararat Stone—Eight Acres of the Land between his own House and the Meeting House—and 110 Acres of Land in Braintree for a fund to erect a Stone Meeting-House, and a Classical School House. To which he has added his whole Library. The town has accepted those gifts upon the Conditions prescribed.

18. VI: Bath with George, and I have commenced upon the experiment of ascertaining what length of time I can swim without over-fatigue. Upon the trials of this week I find from 20 to 25 minutes as long as I can hold it without taking ground. For safety I avoid going beyond my depth, and swim in about five feet of water up and down the river, near the borders of the shore— Mr Little being absent, I heard Mr Lowrie at the Presbyterian Church, upon the 23d. chapter of Numbers; the fruitful, and astonishing character and history of Balaam. Lowrie always takes a whole Chapter for the text of his morning Discourse, which is rather a Lecture than a Sermon. He has learning and eloquence the effect of which is much weakened by an awkward Scottishness of delivery. His expositions of the Scriptures are ingenious and instructive; but his doctrines are bigoted Calvinism. Mr. and Mrs W. S. Smith, and Mr Frye, with Robert Buchanan, dined with us; and I invited Mr and Mrs Smith to come to-morrow and take their abode with me, until they can get settled. I received again a Letter from Mrs Adams, and also one from Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn of Boston, upon the subject of my controversy with Russell— His opinion is very explicit and very strong against Russell, whose constituents he says are much exasperated against him, and mortified; so that he thinks he will not be re-elected to the next Congress. My son Charles is this day fifteen years old.

19. V:30. Bath with George; the last time of the Morning tides of the New Moon. Swam 25 Minutes. Mr Bailey called at my house and left the City, for a visit to New-England— His health is faltering, and an unbroken Summer Residence in Washington, shatters our Northern Constitutions. Mr and Mrs. W. S. Smith came from Mrs Wilson’s to lodge with us— I passed the Evening which was very sultry at home— Answered General Dearborn’s Letters and received one from my wife, chiefly upon an attack against me in one of the Philadelphia newspapers, against me, on account of the negligence of my dress. It says that I wear neither waistcoat nor cravat; and sometimes go to Church barefoot. My wife is much concerned at this, and several of my friends at Philadelphia have spoken to her of it as a serious affair. In the Washington City Gazette some person unknown to me, has taken the cudgels in my behalf, and answered the accusation gravely, as if the charge were true. It is true, only as regards the Cravat, instead of which in the extremity of the Summer heat I wear round my neck a black silk ribband— But even in the falsehoods of this charge, what I may profitably remember is the perpetual and malignant watchfulness with which I am observed in my open day and my secret Night, with the deliberate purpose of exposing me to public obloquy, or public ridicule. There is nothing so deep, and nothing so shallow, which political enmity will not turn to account. Let it be a warning to me to take heed to my ways.

20. V:30.Mr M’Pherson was this morning at my house, upon his application for a Consular appointment, and Edward Wyer, who has always some mysterious news to tell, which invariably turns out to be false: often however with a mixture of truth. I was at the President’s. His daughter Mrs Gouverneur had a son born yesterday— The President spoke to me of the Proclamation, for opening our Ports to British Vessels from their Colonies— He is in some concern at the delay to issue it. I mentioned to him that by Mr Calhoun’s advice, I had sent the draft to Mr R. King, to consult him with regard to the Construction given to the term West Indies, in the Act of Congress upon which it is founded, and upon the reciprocal restrictions to be imposed upon the British Vessels; and had not yet received Mr Kings’ answer— The President approved this but thought if Mr King’s answer should be long delayed it would be necessary to issue the proclamation, without waiting for it— Letter from my wife. Her brother has undergone a second operation, and is in a deep depression of Spirits, with which she naturally sympathizes. Evening at the Play— The School for Scandal, with Colman’s Comic Opera, of Love Laughs at Locksmiths— It was the best Entertainment I have found at the theatre this Season— The School for Scandal was on the whole well performed. Warren’sSir Peter Teazle, and Mrs Anderson’sLady Teazle were both very good acting. The other parts very passably. Jefferson’sCharles Surface good in itself was not the character exactly suited to his talents. His cast is drollery, and buffoonery. He wants youth, and the dress deportment and manners of a Gentleman— His Charles Surface is a failure; but the failure of an excellent performer, which is better than the success of an indifferent one— In the farce, he was more in his Element.

21. VI:Mr Thomas Cook was at my house this morning— Just returned from Philadelphia and Long Branch— Dr Thornton also; Edward Wyer, and Ninian Pinkney, Clerk of the Council in the State of Maryland, and brother to the late celebrated William Pinkney. A Mr Simmes was at the Office. Mr and Mrs and Miss Kerr were here this Evening to visit Mr and Mrs Smith— I received the answer to a Letter which I wrote on the 11th. to R. Walsh— Intending to notice in my pamphlet the publication in his National Gazette of 10 May, of Jonathan Russell’s Letter; and his Editorial comments upon it, and wishing to avoid giving offence to him, I sent him the draft of the few remarks which I propose to add upon that publication— He answers that he is satisfied with the remarks as I sent them to him, and does not object to the publication of them.

22. V:30.Major Roberdeau called upon me at my house, having just returned from Philadelphia, where he saw my wife the day before yesterday— I called at the Comptroller, Andersons Office, to ask for a certified copy of the Settlement of my Accounts, during my last Residence in Europe, which he promised to have made out and sent to me. John Mitchell Agent for the Exchange of Prisoners at Halifax during the late War with Great Britain, came about the settlement of his Accounts. They were settled at the Treasury four or five years since, and a balance of about twelve thousand dollars found due from him. It has so remained until the provision in the appropriation Acts of the last Session of Congress forbidding the payment of current compensation to persons in Arrears to the Government came to bear upon him— He is now a Clerk in the Treasury Department, and his wages being stopped, is likely to be starved out unless he can obtain relief from his Arrears, which he is unable to pay— He now desires that his settled account may be re-opened, and a new allowance made him equal to the whole balance due from him. I told him that this could not be done, but by the express authority of Congress. P. Brown came with his book.

23 V:30.Mr Henry Johnson the Senator from Louisiana, called upon me this morning with Mr Edward Livingston of New-Orleans— Livingston is elected a member of the next Congress from the State of Louisiana, and will probably be one of its most distinguished members. He is a man of very superior talents whose career has been checkered with good and evil, with right and wrong perhaps as much as that of any public man in this Country. He is now going to Richmond Virginia. He asked me whether I had received a copy of his Report to the Legislative of Louisiana, of a project for a criminal code, which he had sent me— I had, and was much pleased with it— I told him there were many of its opinions with which I fully concurred, and some upon which my mind was perhaps not so clearly made up. Mr Stone the engraver came to the Office, and asked me if I could lend him a portrait of my father for the purpose of having a full length engraving of it made as a companion for those of the other Presidents of the United States— King has repeatedly applied to me with a view to take copies, of a picture of my father— I told Stone, I would endeavour to obtain for him the one that I have at Quincy. Mr Calhoun called, and I shewed him the answer I had just received from Mr R. King, returning my draft of a Proclamation, opening our Ports to British Vessels from their American Colonial Ports— Mr King approves of the liberal construction we have given to the term West-Indies in the Act of Congress of the last Session; and he thinks the more enlarged restriction of the Articles importable in British Vessels of West-Indian Articles from the West-Indies and North American Articles from North-America, preferable to the narrower limitation of Articles the produce only of the particular Colony from which the vessel may come. I altered the draft of the Proclamation accordingly to be published in the National Intelligencer to-morrow Morning. Mr Smith unwell.

24. VII.Dr Thornton came in this Morning to recommend to me again as he had several times before the employment of a Mr Keller, to repair arrange, and keep in order the models at the Patent Office: Keller is a German; an ingenious mechanician, who is in distress, and without occupation or means of subsistence. I told the Doctor, that if he would write me a Letter, stating the necessity for repairing and arranging the models I would employ Keller by the day upon it—I wrote to Mr Cruft at Boston requesting him to send me my father’s Portrait— Evening at the Play—Pizarro; and Miss in her Teens— The part of Rolla, was performed by an American Tragedy hero said to be from the Charleston and Richmond Theatres, named Alexander Wilson. He may pass for a respectable actor; but has not much talent— Pizarro is by Sheridan, from Kotzebue, and quite unworthy of the author of the School for Scandal. The farce is Garrick’s, with much attempt at humour, laboured and heavy. The Newspapers this day announce the Death at Lexington Kentucky of Thomas Dougherty Clerk to the House of Representatives of the United States. I received a Letter from my wife, who seems to partake of her brother’s despondency with regard to his health. From her account he is at the worst, and deeply depressed in his Spirits. The Proclamation was published in the three City papers; for the Washington Republican, the paper edited by T. L. M’Kenney, has made its appearance according to the promise of its Prospectus, and comes out on Wednesdays and Saturdays— It beings with a Series of numbers addressed to the People, very well written, and which have unfolded with coolness and with much moderation and decorum of language, the opposition against the present administration, which has been forming itself under the auspices of Mr Crawford, and with a view to promote his election to the Presidency as the Successor of Mr Monroe.

25. V:30. Attended public worship at the second Presbyterian Church and heard Mr Baker, preach from Malachi 2.2. “If ye will not hear, and if ye will not lay it to heart, to give glory unto my
name, saith the Lord of hosts, I will even send a curse upon you, and I will curse your ‘Blessings.” The preacher said that it was not his ordinary practice to hold forth the terrors of the Lord’s anger as admonitions to righteousness; being much more inclined to use with them arguments of kindness and persuasion; but that comminations were also occasionally necessary, and however painful and disagreeable the duty was to perform, it must be discharged— He then gave his explanation of what he understood to be meant by the Lord’s curse, and particularly by the curse upon blessings. His exhortation to flee from the wrath to come was earnest; but not fanatical. After the Sermon, Mr Josiah Meigs, the Commissioner of the Land Office, was ordained by him a Ruling Elder of the Society. The ceremony was short and simple— He first announced that Mr Meigs had been duly elected to the Office of Ruling Elder— Then addressed him personally, upon which he stood up in his own pew— The Minister then enumerated the duties of a Ruling Elder enquiring of Mr Meigs whether he would faithfully perform them— And being answered in the affirmative declared him fully instituted in the Office, and required of the members of the Society to give him all necessary support in the discharge of its duties— I walked this Evening down to Mr Frye’s where I met Mrs Belt, the Sister of the late Mr Walter Hellen.

26. VI: At the Office there came an Agent from Mr Deabbate the Sardinian Consul to enquire whether I had received a Letter from him written a month since or more. He has written me several Letters, and also applied to me in person, stating that American vessels are treated in the Ports of Sardinia, more favourably, with regards to duties and charges than in the Ports of the United States themselves; and demanding that Sardinian vessels should pay no more in the Ports of the United States, than American vessels in the Ports of Sardinia— That is, not so much as our own vessels. And he has supported this demand by fallacious tables of comparative charges— I answered his first Letters, and pointed out the inaccuracy of his tables; besides which I informed him that our Consul at Genoa Mr Schee had represented that discriminating duties were levied in the Sardinian Ports upon our vessels, higher not only than those upon Sardinian vessels, but than those upon British vessels— This Deabbate denies, but as Schee has left Genoa, and deserted his Consulate I have not now the means of ascertaining the facts through him— I have therefore postponed answering Deabbate’s Letters for the present but told his agent that I had received them— I received this day a second Letter from the French Louisianan Lunatic, Le Duc, who sent me small transparent pebbles, which he says he procured in Nova-Scotia, from an old Indian, who took him to a remote and uninhabited region, to what he called diamond mountains, where after swimming across a river, he brought him back these stones which many persons believe to be diamonds, because they cut glass; but he thinks them only fine crystal— After a magnificent panagyric upon Nova-Scotia, which he insists belongs to him, and an argument upon its importance to the United States, he informs me that he can furnish me the means of acquiring it without the expense of a Sous, and asks of me an interview to explain himself. I did not answer his Letter. I wrote to Mrs Adams, and after a long delay answered two Letters from Mr W. N. Boylston— There was a party this Evening at Mr. Calhoun’s, which Mr and Mrs Smith and George attended; from which I excused myself; being slightly indisposed. I nevertheless took a solitary walk by Moonlight, and made a short Evening— The Washington City Gazette has this day come out for the first time with the Treasury Stamp unequivocal upon its face— It has long been at market, apparently between Mr Crawford and me— Really sold to him, years ago, but wishing also to make its price with me. Wyer told me not long since that Elliot the Editor had asked him if I was his friend; complained that I had given him no jobs of printing lately to do— Said that my objection
to his Account for printing papers relating to the Census, had been only a misunderstanding—hinted that he could not afford to be my friend, for nothing— Boasted that he had entirely put down Mr Calhoun’s pretensions to the Presidency; and considered himself as thereby serving me: with a distinct intimation that could serve me as he had served Mr Calhoun. I told Wyer, that I had been obliged to cut down Elliot’s account for the census papers, for its extortions and then told him that I should give him no more work, at the public charge. That he had not put down Mr. Calhoun; and if he had, it was not for the purpose of serving me—And that I should not purchase the services of any printer, either with public money or my own— This was but a few days since, and this day the Gazette shews its flag. It enumerates also the other Newspapers, which it considers as pledged to the same cause, which is obviously to give them a signal of mutual intelligence— The organization of newspaper support for Mr Crawford throughout the Union is very extensive, and is managed with much address, Democracy, Economy, and Reform, are the watchwords, for his recruiting service— Democracy to be used against me— Economy against Calhoun; and Reform against both— Calhoun is organizing a counter-system of Newspaper-Artillery; and his Washington Republican, is already working powerfully in his favour— These Engines will counteract each other; but I shall be a mark for both sides, and having no counterfire upon them, what can happen but that I must fall? This fall may be the happiest event that could befall me, and I but fervently ask that my mind may be disciplined to what ever may betide me; and supported to the level of higher aims than any political fortune can reach—

27. V: Morning bath with George in the Potowmack. There was at the Office a Mr Fordham who came to obtain the authentication of certain papers— They were to prove the marriage nearly sixty years ago of an English Officer named Piety (a name which seems a Satire upon his conduct) with a woman of Pennsylvania; by whom he had several children; and then abandoned her and them; returned to England just before the commencement of the War of the Revolution; there married again, and never came back. He is now dead, and there is an Estate depending upon the proof of this Marriage. Fordham is himself an Englishman, residing in Kentucky, but is now going to England to pursue this affair in behalf of the party interested. There was also a Mr Mahy at the Office, and Mr Calhoun called to make enquiries— He noticed the decisive manner in which the Washington City Gazette came out yesterday in favour of Mr Crawford and against me— He has long considered the Gazette as edited from the Treasury Department, and all the Articles in it against him as coming almost directly from Mr Crawford himself— He says the course Crawford is now pursuing is precisely the same, as he kept in 1815 and 1816. which he had great opportunities of then observing, as he was of the same Mass with two or three of Crawford’s managing partizans— He says that Crawford is a very singular instance of a man of such character rising to the eminence he now occupies— That there has not been in the history of the Union of another man, with abilities so ordinary, with services so slender, and so thoroughly corrupt, who has contrived to make himself a Candidate for the Presidency. He thinks it however impossible that he should succeed— Evening at the Play. Maturin’s Tragedy of Bertram or the Castle of St. Aldobrand; with the Comet, a laughable farce. I found the Tragedy more disgusting in the Representation, than I had upon its first appearance in the reading— Mr George Graham was at the Theatre; he has just returned from a long visit to Kentucky; and says that the People there have got into excessive ill humor with the General Government; and a universal passion for Mr Clay to be the next President: though they are at the same time in a flame of internal combustion, with stop laws, paper money, and hunting down judges in which Clay is
on the unpopular side, which at this time is the side of Justice— At the late Election a decided majority of the State Legislature has been chosen, for removing the Judges who pronounced the relief Laws unconstitutional; and in the Elections for Congress, the Candidates opposed to the administration were every where elected. Clay himself is one of them.

28. V:30. Bath with George. Force here with a proof Sheet, and for more copy. I have finished the writing for my publication; but am yet much occupied in revising as well the manuscript copy to be furnished, and the arrangement of the Collection, as the proof sheets as they are printed from day to day. From the first of July when I received Russell’s publication in the Boston Statesman of 27. June, until yesterday I have been so entirely absorbed in writing and preparing this pamphlet that my Journal has run the whole of that time in arrears— Yesterday I resumed my Diary at the first of July, with my Index and Memory for guides— Wyer came to the Office this day with an air of deep mystery and told me that Dougherty the late Clerk of the House of Representatives had died, a large defaulter of Public Money, and that the real debtor was Mr Clay to whom while he was Speaker of the House Dougherty had advanced it from the funds for paying the compensation of the members— I do not credit this story, though it is highly probable Dougherty may be a defaulter, and not at all impossible that there may be a balance due from Mr Clay. The President with Mr Gouverneur called this Evening to see me, having heard that I was unwell— I called afterwards at Mr Calhoun’s— He had heard nothing of Dougherty’s defalcation.

29. V:30. There was a fire in the Night at a livery stable kept by a man named Smith, whose horses were all burnt— Morning bath and swim with George. Maul the Ex Messenger of the Department of State came, with a solicitation for a petitionary allowance— Cyrus Briggs a Classmate of my Son George’s, who has been sometime residing in a Gentleman’s family in Virginia came to spend a few days with him— Evening at the Play. Othello, and Raising the Wind— Wilson in the part of Othello; and Wheatley in that of Iago—both worse than indifferent. Mrs Anderson as Desdemona was much better— The amusement of the Evening was Jefferson’sJeremy Didler— The Richmond Enquirer of the 27th. which came this day contains a Letter from John Floyd the Member of the House of Representatives who moved last Session for the Ghent Documents and for Russell’s Letters to the Editor of that Paper, who had instigated it, by a stimulant hint in their paper of the 2d. Floyd is a man, having in the main honest intentions, but with an intellect somewhat offuscated, violent passions, suspecting dishonesty and corruption, in all but himself; rashly charging it upon others; eager for distinction, and forming gigantic projects upon crude and half-digested information. He has a plan for establishing a territorial Government at the Mouth of Columbia river; and being leagued with Clay and Benton of Missouri, made his Bill for that purpose the pretext for moving the Calls for the Ghent papers and then for Russell’s Letter— Clay who is at the bottom of it all, has from the day after the signature of the Treaty of Ghent, been working like a Mole, to undermine me in the West, by representing me as an enemy to the Western interests, and by misrepresenting the transactions at Ghent, in a way to suit that purpose— Russell’s Letter of 11. Feby. 1815 was concerted with Clay, who must have supposed that I should be precluded by my situation from making any defence and that the poison would operate, without the counteraction of any antidote. The mismanagement of Russell, blew up their whole plot, and Floyd’s part in it being partly detected he himself has been handled as he deserved in many of the newspaper Commentaries upon the whole transaction. The Richmond Enquirer intent upon bringing out all possible opposition to me, and
knowing the coarseness and insolence of Floyd’s hostility, put forth a provocative to Floyd to come out, and he has come out accordingly; at once crafty and ferocious; pretending self-defence, as if I had injured him—falsely charging me with having asserted that he had made himself subservient to Russell’s purposes, and then imputing direct falsehood to that assertion— Pretending to take no part in the dispute between Russell and me, that he may discharge his venom upon me with more affect under the colour of neutrality— The Washington Gazette in its allegiance to the Treasury now copies every Article against me, from all quarters of the Union, usually with the addition of a thrust at me of its own, by way of Commentary— It republied this afternoon Floyd’s Letter with such a comment; turning it against me, and using it as a lift for Russell.

30. VI:Floyd’s Letter was published this morning in the National Intelligencer. I wrote a very short answer to it, for publication in the same paper to-morrow Morning— Among the absurdities with which Floyd’s Letter abounds is his attacking me in the Newspapers with a charge that I am seeking Newspaper Controversy— I have confined my answers to a direct denial of having made the assertion which he imputes to me, and declares false, and have fixed the falsehood unanswerably upon himself— The City Gazette of this afternoon has another insulting paragraph, of high panegyrick upon Floyd’s character, purity of motives and veracity, and asserting that his Letter puts the dispute between Russell and me upon an entire new footing— This is followed by a paragraph hoping that I have not employed Seth Hunt (as my enemies insinuate) to plot the destruction of Mr. Russell’s character, for a reward in case of success. This alludes to a charge published in the New York Statesman under the signature of Ariel, charging Russell with having speculated for pecuniary profit upon information which he gave to commercial houses at the Negotiation of Ghent— Russell having called upon the publishers for the name of the author of Ariel, Hunt wrote to him and avowed himself as the author, upon which Russell prosecuted him both by action and by Indictment, and prosecuted also the publishers of the Statesman— Of all these transactions I have no knowledge but by the newspapers.— There are other paragraphs in this days Gazette equally insidious and base, interspersed with encomiums and defences of Crawford, written as I have reason to suppose by a man named Richards of spotted character, whom Crawford knowing him as such has this Summer taken as a Clerk into the Treasury Department— I note these things as they pass to indicate for memory hereafter, the situation in which I am placed, the means used to ruin my character, the agents by whom the machinery is wielded, and the persons for whom the dirty work is performed— The thing itself is not new— From the nature of our Institutions the competitors for public favour, and their respective partizans seek success by Slander upon each other as you add to the weight of one Scale, by taking from that of the other. I disdain this ignoble mode of warfare, and neither wage it myself nor countenance it in my friends. But from present appearances it will decide the succession to the Presidency— I was idle at the Office, and received a Letter from Joseph R. Ingersoll, intimating an apprehension that it might be necessary to take over again my deposition in the case of Harris vs Lewis— I spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s.

31. V:30. A Mr M. S. Scott came to my house— And Leduc the Louisianian. He explained to me his claims to the property of the Province of Nova-Scotia, and the attempts he had made to give them legal effect there. Unfortunately the Lawyers were all against him, and the Duke of Richmond told him that his claim could be decided upon only in England. What he wanted
was funds to prosecute his claim, and his proposal was that the Government of the United States should make him an advance of money for that purpose. Success was infallible, upon which he would not only repay all the advances, but transfer upon the most moderate terms the property of the Province itself to the United States. I told him that it would not suit the views of the Government to make advances of money upon a claim in litigation, and returned him his pebbles, which he supposed might be diamonds— There is nothing in the man’s appearance or deportment which indicates insanity— His language is correct both in writing and discourse. His personal aspect is grave, his address decent and respectful, and his apparent standing in Society respectable. He told me, and had already mentioned in his last Letter; that he had written to General Jackson concerning his right to the Province of Nova-Scotia— Edward Wyer was here, and told me, that Richards who has been sometime absent, returned to the City about three days since; and has already shewn his stamp in the City Gazette. I called at Mr Anderson the Comptroller’s Office, and asked him for a certified copy of my account as finally settled at the Treasury; which he promised to have made out and sent to me— I answered Jos. Ingersoll’s Letter— Evening at the Play— Alexander the Great, and the Prize, or 2, 5, 3, 8. both of which I had seen before— It was Wilson’s benefit Night and he performed the part of Alexander— There was hardly a house to pay the expenses of the Night. The Play itself was ill chosen; being a showy exhibition for which they are about as well furnished, as Romeo’s apothecary would be to assume the part of a Persian King— Jefferson’sDr Lenitive in the farce made up for deficiencies in the Tragedy— My answer to Floyd’s charge was published in the National Intelligencer this Morning—and copied into the Evening paper— In the City Gazette, with an affected and mawkish paragraph of commentary, and with other malignant paragraphs against me.30. Novr. 1795.

Day. The distribution of my time is not different from that of the last Month— My occupation has been constant in preparing for the publication of my pamphlet— I had hoped the writing for it was finished, and revised my diary this week at the close of June, where it had been suspended but I only came to the 6th. of July, and am now forced to drop it again. I am writing further remarks upon Floyd’s Letter— The revisal of the proof sheets takes me about an hour every day; and my attendance at my Office is uninterrupted, though too much of my time is absorbed by inofficial employment.
